posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked:
When our robot is enabled, the swerve modules jerk around to random angles every 10 seconds or so. This started after we changed our cancoder initialization strategy to BootToAbsolute.

Before, when we had it on BootToZero, we experienced a different issue: the swerve modules would offset themselves by our specified steer offset with every redeploy.

What is the root cause of this? Please help :​(
Sounds like your magnets aren’t glued in for your absolute magnetic encoder.

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: I’m thinking it may be a code issue (we deployed to a known, working robot and it had the same issue)
Can you link to your code?

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: Turns out the magnets on both robots might not have been glued. If we glue them and it doesn’t fix it then I’ll link code.

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: Gluing didn’t work, so here’s a snippet of our back left swerve module creation (we are using MK4s)

posts.name: Silas
posts.cooked:
This is a common issue, have you read this thread yet? You may find something helpful in there, particularly to the bottom.

Edit: appears you issue is different, sorry! Best of luck

link_counts.title: Swerve Modules Rotate Upon First Enable

posts.name: Colin Wong
posts.cooked: What’s different in the code between the known working robot and the current code? Identifying that difference might help diagnose the issue.

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked: The code for our old robot was displaying this issue as well. We’ve since fixed our jittery wheels by booting each encoder to zero and then loading the absolute position later, but now we have a different issue: our modules won’t respond to steer offsets at all. Do you have any idea why this might be happening?

posts.name: Adam
posts.cooked:
We finally found a solution to this after about a week lol. Basically, it had to do with this section in our Falcon500SteerControllerFactoryBuilder class (which we got from democat’s library)

We discovered that our wheels were jittering once every 10 seconds, and lo and behold, this method seeds the position of the TalonFXs every 10 seconds. We commented this out and the jittering stopped. We do have to manually turn our wheels forward every time we deploy code, but at least it can drive ig.

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
